entry.title: MM43 - restriction of finance view permerchandise categories without restricting material master dat
entry.content:
Dear community,

I am seeking your help as I have a customer requirement to access MM43 as follows:
- Population 1: Shouldn't have access to finance view (Standard price & CCR) for any materia, but should keep access to basic data for all materials
- Population 2: Should have access to finance view (Standard price & CCR) for finished products only, but should keep access to basic data for all materials
- Population 3: Should have access to finance view (Standard price & CCR) for components only, but should keep access to basic data for all materials

I understand that restricting the finance view implies restricting authorizations in field BEGRU of M_MATE_MAR auth object. But the issue is that it will impact access to basic master data too.

For example for population 2, if we restrict BEGRU field to include finished products only, this population will lose access to basic data of other merchandise categories. Which cannot be accepted.

Would you have any recommendation (or solution) to apply the customer requirements?

Thank you very much

entry.title: Review Booklets and Multidimensional Analysis Apps: What you need to know about Accessibility?
entry.content:
Introduction 

Review Booklets and Multidimensional Analysis Applications have made significant progress towards modernizing the reporting capabilities in S/4HANA. This greatly improves the ability of business user to monitor your business and obtain business insights within embedded analytics. Those capabilities have now matured to the point where they are ready for mainstream consumption. In this blog we would like to focus on important aspects of usability and accessibility.

Please remember the previous blogs and documentation regarding those reporting apps from earlier releases:

- www.help.sap.com

- Multidimensional Analysis a Stepstone to modern Reporting in S/4HANA 

Those reporting apps have become more and more insightful, deliver standard reporting out-of the box with immediate real-time access to data, within the known Fiori user experience, and without additional installations or efforts. 

Here is a short overview of the most important features:

Figure 1: Use Cases

Important features are:

  • guided business pages and layouts, optimized for typical business questions
  • generic pivoting and drill-down in layout side panel
  • filtering on booklet and page level
  • contextual navigation using intent-based navigation
  • cell-based commenting and page comments
  • AI assisted Business insights
  • collaboration on business pages in teams and on comments using notifications
  • copy, create and adapt booklets within key user extensibility or
  • create new booklets as customer developer using embedded steampunk

The Accessibility Approach:

An important step towards maturity is the question: How can advanced reporting meet the standards of accessibility?
Accessibility needs to ensure that everyone can effectively use and interact with complex multidimensional analytical tasks, regardless of whether they have disabilities or not. Here are some important aspects to consider:

  1. Intuitive Interface Design including simple and consistent layout, easy to understand with intuitive navigation
    - Simplicity in "Accessibility and Fullscreen mode"
    - Simple Screen Titles, Headings and accessible alternatives
  2. Visual Perception and Readability
    - Text Resizing
    - Color and Contrast Setting,
    - Responsive Design,
  3. Key Board Navigation
    - Consistent navigation and Context menus
    - Key board focus,  Group Skipping, etc.
  4. Assistive Tool Support  and Screen Reader

Those topics will be illustrated and explained in this blog.
Please note that there are many usability features that are very useful for everyone.

Intuitive User Interface and Accessibility/Fullscreen Mode

A typical review booklet combines multiple pages prepared to answer the most typical business question in a certain area.

The information is offered through a user-Interface consisting of a "Filter Bar", multiple "Business Pages", "Combo Boxes", "Table/Grid with Context Menus" and "Side Panels" offering different features and capabilities:

Figure 2: User Interface Elements

A typical example might look like the screen below.
For users with disabilities or impairments, it might be challenging to access the different controls and interact with the many features, ranging from filtering and changing the layout to advanced pivoting. 


Figure 3: From Review Booklet to full-screen mode

Nevertheless "Review Booklets" and "Multidimensional Applications" are designed with accessibility and usability in mind.

To simplify the screen,  we offer a full screen mode, which also serves as an accessibility mode. See Figure 3.
Each feature is available through an accessible alternative within the context menu. See more details in the chapter key board navigation and figure 6.

Figure 4: Agenda View in full-screen mode
In full-screen mode you work and explore the current page, but you can easily access all pages via a simple agenda view,  as shown in Figure 4.

Visual Perception and Readability

This allows you to zoom into the details and ensure that all the details are easy to read.
Combined with theming (for example the High Contrast Black Theme)  and responsive design, the readability can be increased dramatically. 
 

Figure 5: High Contrast Black Horizon Theme

Key Board Navigation

Keyboard navigation is a convenient way to move the focus in your application without using the mouse. By using Tab and Shift Tab you can move the focus to the next element on the screen. Group Skipping -  F6 and Shift F6 allows you to quickly jump between groups of elements such as the filter bar, table or side panel.

Figure 6: Opening context menu to access all features

As already mentioned before, the most important feature is to launch the context menu using Ctrl Shift F10.

 This gives you easy access to all available feature via an accessible path

  • the layout can be changed by
    • adding, removing or moving dimensions to rows and columns
    • Hierarchy handling or
    • Filtering
  • in addition you can open accessible a side panels to work on 
    • page filters
    • comments
    • export to Excel and PDF
  • or use contextual navigation

Assistive Tool Support  and Screen Reader

Assistive tool support and screen readers are crucial for visually impaired individuals to access digital content. The recommended screen reader is JAWS (Job Access With Speech), which reads the content on the screen aloud, allowing users to navigate and interact with their computers using text-to-speech technology. JAWS can describe icons, menus, and other screen elements, making it easier for people with visual impairments to use applications and websites independently.

Especially for screen reader use cases, it is very important that every cell contains the full information.
Merged cells are cause trouble because relevant information gets lost.
This can be fixed by showing the content of merged cells as shown in the screenshot below.

Figure 7: Display the content of merged cells

In addition, we can also move the currency into the related amount cell using the formatting side panel.
By default the currency is typically shown in the column header, which also causes issues in screen reader use cases.

Figure 8: How to add currency or Unit to Data Cells

Ressources:
Accessibilty Features in Review Booklets
https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/6b356c79dea443c4bbeeaf0865e04207/e14ea59510d54bf1979ae7fc11a5cda4.html

entry.title: SAP Central Finance in SAP Sovereign Cloud and SAP NS2
entry.content:
SAP Central Finance in SAP Sovereign Cloud and SAP NS2

We are excited to announce that SAP Central Finance, Private Edition is now generally available in SAP Sovereign Cloud and in SAP National Security Services (NS2).

This new deployment option unlocks the capabilities and benefits of SAP Central Finance for customers with highest security and compliance requirements who cannot use the standard private cloud environment. This is important in particular for customers operating in specific industries, like defense & security, public sector or regulated industries.

 

What is SAP Sovereign Cloud in a nutshell?

SAP Sovereign Cloud

  • is designed to help organizations adopt cloud technologies while maintaining full control over their data, infrastructure, and compliance
  • goes beyond basic digital sovereignty to meet advanced compliance requirements across four key dimensions: data, operational, technical and legal sovereignty
  • is available in selected countries and offers tailored solutions aligned with local regulatory standards

 

What is Central Finance in a nutshell?

Central Finance is a solution which builds bridges between systems and helps companies in their business transformation. With Central Finance you can connect SAP and Non-SAP systems to an SAP S/4HANA Central Finance system and leverage a harmonized financial reporting across legal entities or enable a centralized financial processing (e.g. shared services for Finance). Central Finance helps companies to move into the cloud, to adopt latest innovation of S/4HANA Cloud including Business AI for Finance, and to transform step by step to an agile company with self-defined pace.

For more information on Central Finance, please explore SAP S/4HANA Cloud for Central Finance.

 

What is the release status and scope of Central Finance in SAP Sovereign Cloud and SAP NS2?

SAP Central Finance is successfully validated and certified on SAP Sovereign Cloud and SAP NS2. This validation includes full technical and security validation. First customers are already live with Central Finance in the NS2 environment.

The Sovereign Cloud release of SAP Central Finance, Private Edition is currently available in following countries:

  • Australia / New Zealand
  • Canada
  • United Kingdom
  • United States (NS2)

 Please note that Sovereign Cloud is available on different infrastructures in those regions, e.g. hyperscalers like AWS or Azure.  

 

Below please find an overview which CFIN relevant products are released in the Sovereign Cloud in selected regions:

Product

Status

SAP S/4HANA Cloud for Central Finance Foundation, Private Edition

Available

SAP S/4HANA Cloud for Central Finance Foundation, Private Edition, Tailored Option

On Request

SAP Landscape Transformation Replication Server for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition

Available

SAP Central Finance Data Harmonization by Magnitude, Priv Ed, Tailored Option

On Request

SAP Central Finance Transaction Replication by Magnitude, Priv Ed, Tailored Option

On Request

 

Every customer landscape is unique and that is also valid for the Central Finance architecture. There can be variances in each and every deployment, but there are roughly two deployment options to be considered, depending on the existing customer landscape:

 Option 1 (standard option)

 

Option 2*

*e.g. for customers who are already using a stand-alone SLT server

 

The offering in Sovereign Cloud continues to be extended ‚Äì so please stay tuned! üîä

entry.title: Failure in Hana integration with SAP DM in Classification Assignment Download messages.
entry.content:
Dear Colleagues,
I hope you are all well.

I am facing a problem integrating Material Master Data from our SAP system (S/4HANA) to SAP Digital Manufacturing (DM), and I would like to know if anyone in the community has encountered or has knowledge about this situation.

The Problem:
When executing the DRFOUT transaction to replicate multiple materials to Digital Manufacturing, the observed behavior is as follows:
‚Ä¢ Material Master Data (MATMAS) messages are sent and processed correctly in Digital Manufacturing.
‚Ä¢ However, Classification Assignment Download messages for these materials are not being sent or downloaded correctly in their entirety.

‚Ä¢ Some classification assignment messages are missing or not being generated/sent to DM, resulting in incomplete or missing classification data for some of the materials in the target system.

My Questions:
1. Has anyone encountered a similar scenario where classification messages are not reliably sent when replicating multiple materials via DRFOUT?
2. Is there any SAP Note or specific setting in DRFOUT or Customizing that might be limiting the sending of these secondary messages when the volume of materials is high?

3. What would be the recommended path to debug/trace the failure in generating/sending the Classification Assignment message (IDoc or service) after the MATMAS has been generated?

Any insight, tip, or documentation reference would be extremely helpful.

Thank you immensely for your attention and collaboration.

Sincerely,

entry.title: How to Prepare for SAP‚Äôs New Certification
entry.content:
For years, SAP certification relied on multiple-choice questions and memorized answers. That approach no longer fits the realities of modern SAP work, where professionals configure systems, solve business problems, and increasingly collaborate with AI-driven tools. Simply recalling information isn‚Äôt enough.

The new SAP certification model shifts the focus from ‚Äúknowing SAP‚Äù to ‚Äúdoing SAP,‚Äù i.e., applying skills in real-world scenarios, navigating tools, and demonstrating practical competence.

If you‚Äôre planning to get certified soon, your preparation needs to evolve with it.

What‚Äôs Changing and What It Means for Your Preparation

SAP‚Äôs new practical certification exams introduce a more authentic and performance-oriented approach to skill validation. Instead of testing whether you can recall a configuration detail, the new exams examine whether you can complete tasks, solve problems, and make decisions in situations that resemble real project environments.

They use two primary formats: System-based assessment and Scenario-based assessment.

The System-based assessment is where learners work inside a time-limited SAP system simulation. You are required to perform actual tasks, such as configuring components, building processes, developing artifacts, or resolving issues, just as you would in a project environment. The assessment measures your fluency in SAP tools, your ability to execute steps accurately, and your ability to apply best practices in a live system.

The Scenario-based assessment places you in time-limited role-play situations with an AI avatar. In these scenarios, you must pitch SAP solutions, advise on architecture, justify design choices, respond to stakeholder concerns, and guide the conversation toward appropriate outcomes. Rather than executing system tasks, this format evaluates how you think, communicate, analyse requirements, and represent SAP‚Äôs capabilities in a business context.

Each certification will use only one format, either system-based or scenario-based, depending on the nature of the role being assessed. Technical roles emphasise hands-on execution, while consulting and architecture roles prioritise analytical and advisory depth. This creates a more precise and meaningful measurement of job readiness.

The exams are also now open-book, allowing access to documentation, help portals, and AI-assisted guidance during the assessment. This change reflects how professionals actually work. They consult resources, verify information, test assumptions, and use intelligent tools like SAP Joule to support decision-making. The exam rewards the ability to locate, interpret, and apply information under realistic constraints.

SAP is rolling out this new model in phases. The first six certifications are already live and have received a strong response from the ecosystem.

Click this link to access the SAP Certifications featuring practical exams.

How to Prepare for SAP's New Certification

Train on SAP Systems

Hands-on experience is now the most important part of certification readiness. Since the new exams rely heavily on real system usage or scenario execution, you must become comfortable navigating SAP environments directly. Spend time configuring components, building workflows, testing integrations, and troubleshooting issues in SAP BTP,  SAP Build, and other relevant tools.

Memorizing theory will not substitute for actual system familiarity, so create consistent practice sessions that mirror the tasks you expect to face in real projects.

Adopt an Open-Book Learning Mindset

Because SAP‚Äôs new exams allow access to documentation and official resources, your success depends on how efficiently you can locate and apply information. Instead of trying to memorize every detail, shift your focus toward learning how SAP documentation is structured, where key topics are located, and how to interpret guidance quickly under time constraints.

During preparation, challenge yourself to answer questions by navigating documentation rather than recalling facts.

Practise Scenario-Based Problem Solving

The new certification format rewards professionals who can think in end-to-end scenarios rather than isolated tasks. To build this skill, spend time working through full business situations that could appear in an exam.

Imagine a client wants to automate approval workflows, integrate an external application, or modernize their analytics landscape. Break down how you would approach the requirement, which SAP tools you would use, what architecture makes sense, and what risks or trade-offs you would consider.

The more you practise this style of thinking, the more natural it becomes to articulate decisions and explain your reasoning during a scenario-based assessment.

Strengthen Your Architecture and Data Foundations

Modern SAP work revolves around cloud services, data modeling, integration patterns, event-driven design, and automation. To prepare for the new certifications, make time to revisit these fundamentals. Understanding how components fit together will help you make informed decisions, whether you are configuring a system or advising a simulated stakeholder. This broader technical foundation also enables you to respond effectively during role-plays that require architectural justification or strategic recommendations.

Build a Continuous Learning Habit

The redesigned certification model encourages professionals to keep their skills active rather than rely on one-time exam success. As SAP continues to evolve its tools and expand its AI-driven capabilities, staying connected to the ecosystem, whether through hands-on practice, learning content, or experimentation with new features, will help you remain prepared for renewals and future certifications.

What These Changes Mean for Your Career

The new certification format narrows the gap between being certified and being project-ready.

As the assessments test actual capability, credentials earned under this model will carry greater weight with employers seeking professionals who can contribute immediately. It also shifts the ecosystem toward continuous learning, where staying certified means staying active, hands-on, and connected to SAP‚Äôs evolving technologies.

The certifications also mark an important milestone in SAP‚Äôs broader commitment to equip 12 million people worldwide with AI-ready skills by 2030.

If you approach your learning with the mindset of becoming truly project-ready rather than simply exam-ready, you will not only succeed in the new certification format but also build a stronger, more sustainable foundation for your SAP career.

The exam has evolved, and your preparation needs to evolve with it, too.

entry.title: Re: how to group per cost center the depreciation posting
entry.content:
Hi,
In SAP S/4HANA, standard depreciation posting via AFAB does not support grouping line items by cost center instead of by individual asset. Each asset's depreciation is posted separately, even if multiple assets belong to the same cost center

Best Regards

Abdul Baser

entry.title: Use function .rankBy on charts with measures from a measure input control
entry.content:
We have a chart where the measure is controlled over a measure input control. With this setup it is not possible to use the rankBy function as far as I can see?

I can get a measure code with getMembers(FeedAxis) but I cannot use it. It looks like this: 25123745-7560-4113-3967-727090252387

This seems to be the artificial measure code for the measure input control.

When use the measure that is currently selected in the measure input control, which is also the measure if you retrieve the resultSet of a chart, it doesn't work either:
Ranking isn‚Äôt applied because the structure member 00O2THUHN03AJWRF2G2DRG5G7 isn‚Äôt on the chart.

Even though this is the measure that is returned by the resultSet (but in the builder the measure is the measure input control).

I can workaround with doing the measure input control essentially myself, but this is more effort.
It seems quite an obvious requirement from a developer perspective, so I somehow can' t believe that it is not possible.
Am I missing something here?

Kind regards,
Harald

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.3: Final What's New & Product Assistance available
entry.content:
With immediate effect, the final What's New information for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.3 is now available.

To access the final What‚Äôs New information, please use the What‚Äôs New Viewer. In addition, the final Product Assistance (aka Application Help) for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.3 is available. Please use the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Help Portal page to access it.

For you as a customer, we recommend to also use the Release Assessment and Scope Dependency (RASD) tool. The Release Assessment and Scope Dependency (RASD) tool provides you with a personalized and tailored view on What‚Äôs New information based on the activated and used scope within your system. The information for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.3 will be available in RASD within the next few days. A valid Customer S-user ID is required for login. We recommend to use RASD to prepare for upgrades and updates of your system and to focus on the new and changed features that are relevant for you as a customer.

You can use the commenting feature for What‚Äôs New. With this feature, authors can evaluate your feedback and incorporate it into the documentation, if needed. We hope that by opening this channel of communication, we can learn how to further improve our What‚Äôs New content for you. To use this feature, you need to be logged into the Help Portal. The feature will only be available in the English version of the documents. To learn more about how the feedback process works in SAP Help Portal, see Giving Documentation Feedback.

entry.title: Re: Erfassung Wertkorrektur vom ERP Bestand - ohne den EW...
entry.content:
Hallo David,
Wie du bereits erw√§hnt hast, m√ºssen Sie zum √Ñndern der Bewertungsklasse in SAP zun√§chst den Bestand auf null reduzieren, den Materialstamm aktualisieren und anschlie√üend den Bestand neu buchen. Der genaue Ablauf h√§ngt von Ihrer Systemkonfiguration ab. Hier finden Sie eine vereinfachte Anleitung.

Bitte folgen Sie den Schritten zur √Ñnderung der Bewertungsklasse in SAP:

Die √Ñnderung der Bewertungsklasse f√ºr Materialien in SAP erfordert sorgf√§ltige Vorgehensweise, um buchhalterische Inkonsistenzen zu vermeiden. Die einzelnen Schritte sind unten aufgef√ºhrt:

1. Bestand ausbuchen (Bestand auf null setzen)
Bevor Sie die Bewertungsklasse √§ndern, m√ºssen Sie sicherstellen, dass das Material keinen Bestand mehr hat. Dies erreichen Sie wie folgt:
Verwenden Sie die Bewegungsart 551 (Verschrottung).
Transaktionscode: MB1A oder MIGO
W√§hlen Sie die Bewegungsart 551 (Verschrottung).
Geben Sie die Materialnummer, die Menge und das Werk ein.
Buchen Sie den Beleg, um den Bestand aus dem Lager zu entfernen.

Alternative: Bestandsanpassung
Transaktionscode: MI01 (Inventurbeleg anlegen)
Transaktionscode: MI04 (Bestand erfassen)
Transaktionscode: MI07 (Differenzen buchen)
Setzen Sie den Bestand auf null, um den Bestand auszubuchen.

2. Bewertungsklasse √§ndern
Sobald der Bestand null ist:
Transaktionscode: MM02 (Materialstammsatz √§ndern)
Wechseln Sie zur Sicht ‚ÄûBuchhaltung 1‚Äú.
Aktualisieren Sie das Feld ‚ÄûBewertungsklasse‚Äú.

Speichern Sie die √Ñnderungen.

Wenn eine Fehlermeldung wie ‚ÄûBuchung in den Bilanzgruppen nicht ausgeglichen‚Äú erscheint, kann dies an offenen Bestellungen oder Buchhaltungsbelegen liegen, die mit der alten Bewertungsklasse verkn√ºpft sind.

3. Bestand wieder einbuchen
Nach Aktualisierung der Bewertungsklasse:
Verwenden Sie die Bewegungsart 561 (Anfangsbuchung):
Transaktionscode: MB1C oder MIGO
W√§hlen Sie die Bewegungsart 561.
Geben Sie die Materialnummer, die Menge und das Werk ein.

Buchen Sie den Beleg, um den Bestand wieder einzuf√ºhren.

Ich hoffe, das hilft Ihnen bei der √Ñnderung der Bewertungsklasse.

entry.title: Questions about SAP ECC on-premise to S/4HANA Private Cloud Conversion
entry.content:
Hello SAP Experts,

I am preparing for a SAP ECC on-premise to S/4HANA Private Cloud conversion and have several questions regarding the process and access requirements:

 

- Does the SAP provider install and prepare the S/4HANA system with the correct version and HANA database?

- Can the customer run the Readiness Check on the ECC source system? Is it the same as for an on-premise conversion?

- What type of access is provided for the private cloud system (e.g., root, GUI, HANA DB)?

- How is the SUM (Software Update Manager) executed on the source ECC system, and how should I select the migration option (DMO with System Move / DMOVE2S4)?

- Is it necessary to download and upload files to the target system for DMO with System Move?

- Will I have root system access to directories like /usr/sap/<SID>/SUM?

- Are the standard HANA directories on the cloud target the same as on-premise (e.g., /hana/shared, /hana/data, /hana/log)?

- How do I launch SUM on the cloud OS target for content migration?

- Should I prepare a sandbox system, or is it handled directly on the production system in the private cloud?

- If there is any migration failure, is it possible to reset and retry safely?

- I would appreciate any guidance, best practices, or tips for planning this migration to S/4HANA Private Cloud.

- I've seen in serval SAP blogs that it's recommended to install an AAS on the private cloud, connect it to the source system, and then run SUM directly on that AAS.

 

Thank you in advance! 

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition Service SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit SAP S/4HANA Cloud, extended edition SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit

entry.title: How Joule Connects to SAP Business One - Actions
entry.content:
Joule Studio's capabilities allow it to connect to a data source, in our case SAP Business One, thanks to Actions, and this is a central and fundamental concept.

Actions in SAP Build are components that allow you to Create, Read, Update or Delete (CRUD) data through Destinations, which in turn connect to the Service Layer.

If you want to delve deeper into Actions, I recommend the following link: ODATA - Actions 

Currently, Actions can be created using the OpenAPI Specification 3.0, but this doesn't yet exist for the SAP Business One Service Layer. It has been documented in a requirement that you can find at this link: https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/idea/311258 

However, we can create Actions from scratch. This requires a solid understanding of how to use the SAP Service Layer, as well as access to it.

I'll explain how they are created, tested, and consumed using Joule Studio's skills; if you master this, you'll be ready to move forward.

Step 1

Direct link: https://youtu.be/3vmdXuFYenM?si=wfnTwnZMpxm5R1g3 

Step 2

Now that we have the Action published, we go to the Joule Studio skill, add it, and configure the input we added, this will make Joule ask the user for the Service call number.

If the response is successful, Joule will be able to answer the user's queries, I'll explain this in another post.

Best regards.

Erick G√≥mez

entry.title: Re: How to maintain texts in table T156HT for different languages (Movement Type Help Texts)
entry.content: Hi, T156HT must be maintained manually; it is not automatically updated via OMJJ. You can use transaction SE61 to maintain help texts per language.

entry.title: Handling Long Field Names in OData / RAP API's
entry.content:
Requuirement:-

While working with OData services in SAP, you might encounter an issue when sending long field
names like: PuchaseOrdernosendtosalesforcesystem

In such cases, your CDS view might throw an error due to the length or naming restriction.

Error Description

 

Solution

Use the annotation below to define the desired long field name explicitly:

@odata.property.name: 'PuchaseOrdernosendtosalesforcesystem'


After adding this annotation, activate your CDS view, and then create:

  • Service Definition
  • Service Binding (V4)

Output on POSTMAN / SAP Gateway

This simple technique helps you maintain meaningful field names without breaking technical limits in Odata API‚Äôs.

Thanks

Dinesh Kumar

entry.title: Re: Error in archiving for HRCUSTAX object
entry.content:
Hello,

it seems you have some inconsistencies in your data for that employee.

Please check the 2 entries using transaction SE16n ensuring all key components (PERNR, INFTY, SUBTY, BEGDA, ENDDA) match exactly the key in the error message.

In addition, you could execute report RPUFIXDS to know if there are any Data Inconsistencies for that employee and eventually fix them.

Finally, please review configuration  on table V_T7XSSPERSUBTY: check if there are entries for IT0161 subtype FED and IT0210 subtype FED.

Best Regards

Giorgio

entry.title: SAP CAP Development Day, Copenhagen
entry.content:
Join us for an inspiring day dedicated to the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP), featuring practical insights, expert sessions, and interactive discussion.

Agenda for the day:

10:00 ‚Äì 10:15 - Welcome & Introduction

10:15 ‚Äì 11:30 - SAP CAP Overview & SAP AI for Developers with Venu Chembrakalathil, SAP

  • Develop cloud native applications in SAP Business Technology Platform using SAP Cloud Application Programming model with best practices served out of the box.
  • Rapid application development with minimal setup and cost, build applications in shorter development cycles.
  • Focus on domain modeling , service definitions using core data services(CDS) , generating data base schema out of the box and expose services as OData APIs without writing custom code.
  • Increase productivity using AI coding assistant and accelerate development.

11:30 ‚Äì 12:30 - Interactive Group Sessions

12:30 ‚Äì 13:15 - Networking Lunch

13:15 ‚Äì 14:30 - Deep Dive into SAP Fiori and Key Elements - Presented by Melwyn Monis, Gavdi Technology

14:30 ‚Äì 15:00 - Q&A and Closing Remarks

Join us for an inspiring day dedicated to the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP), featuring practical insights, expert sessions, and interactive discussions.

üìÖ Date & Time: 27 November, 10:00 ‚Äì 15:00 CET

entry.title: New Learning Journey : Implementing SAP Customer Data Platform
entry.content:
Announcing: Implementing SAP Customer Data Platform Learning Journey

We are thrilled to announce the launch of our extensive learning journey,  Implementing SAP Customer Data Platform . This carefully designed program is crafted to equip you with the advanced skills and in-depth knowledge necessary to harness the full potential of SAP's powerful Customer Data Platform (CDP).

Who this is for:
Target audience: Business users, Admin users, Consultants and Developers  who want to expand their functional knowledge and technical skills with SAP Customer Data Platform.

What You Will Learn:

Mastering Foundations and Configuration

The journey begins with Exploring SAP Customer Data Platform Essentials . This course will guide you through the foundations of SAP Customer Data Platform and help you evaluate the functionalities for your implementation scenarios. This foundational understanding is crucial for effectively leveraging the capabilities of the CDP.

Proficient Administration and Monitoring

In the second course, Administering SAP Customer Data Platform , you will become proficient in performing various administrative tasks within the SAP Customer Data Platform Console. This includes managing console users, dividing business units, defining data retention rules, and utilizing export/import package functionalities. Additionally, you will learn to effectively use monitoring capabilities to ensure seamless ingestion and activation of customer data, thus maintaining optimal performance and compliance.

API Utilization and Data Enrichment

The third course, Developing with SAP Customer Data Platform , focuses on API utilization. You will learn to create and manage administrative credentials for accessing the SAP Customer Data Platform API, construct code to utilize the Query and Ingestion APIs, perform Event Metadata configuration, set up an Event Listener, and program and configure Events to enrich Customer Data. This hands-on experience will empower you to integrate and enhance your customer data ecosystem seamlessly.

AI-Powered Customer Insights and Predictive Analytics

The fourth course, Exploring the SAP Customer Data Platform's AI Workbench , delves into the power of AI-driven insights. You will learn to create activity indicators powered by AI to predict future customer loss or determine the value of your customer base. Moreover, you will gain the ability to gather additional insights using analytical graphics to understand future trends in individual customer churn or lifetime value, all through the SAP Customer Data Platform AI Workbench models and insights.

Hands-On Practice System

To cement your learning, we provide a preconfigured practice system with all the data you need to carry out exercises from the courses or to experiment on your own. The Hands-on Practice for SAP Customer Data Platform Implementation Training  system is invaluable for reinforcing and applying the skills you acquire throughout the learning journey in practical scenarios.

The Implementing SAP Customer Data Platform learning journey is your gateway to mastering one of the most powerful customer data tools available today. Whether you are a beginner or an experienced professional looking to upgrade your skills, this journey will equip you with the advanced expertise needed to drive customer data strategies successfully.

Certification Opportunity: Upon completion of this learning journey, you will be well-prepared to earn a valuable certification, validating your skills and knowledge in SAP Customer Data Platform.

Join us and unlock the full potential of SAP Customer Data Platform. Enrol now and take the first step toward advanced customer data management and analytics.

How to access:
The learning journey is available now on learning.sap.com. The courses are FREE. The practice system requires an SAP Learning Hub license.

entry.title: Joule in SAP Build Code can now create freestyle UI5 apps
entry.content:
Last year, we introduced the SAPUI5 extension for the Joule coding assistant in SAP Build Code and wrote about how to use it. Over time, it has received more features, like the AI-supported conversion of UI5 apps to TypeScript and setting up new pages and the respective navigation.

The latest improvement, available from November 2025, lets you create new freestyle UI5 apps according to your requirements. The feature is not absolutely groundbreaking, as there are other tools doing a similar job like the Easy-UI5 templates and the recently published UI5 MCP Server. But:

  1. It brings the functionality right to the fingertips of developers using SAP Build Code‚Äîno other tools needed.
  2. It extends the template capabilities beyond what the Easy-UI5 templates provide.
  3. Implementing it within the Build Code Joule environment yielded interesting insights and further improvements. More on this in my other article.

 

The feature

Joule makes specific features available using "slash commands". The new one is /ui5-create-app. When you open the Joule panel in SAP Build Code and start typing /ui5, you might see it suggested, as well as other UI5 features. But which commands appear depends on the context. While some are only available within UI5 apps, this new feature is only available when you are not in a UI5 app. It won't be available e.g. in a workspace which has a ui5.yaml at top-level, or when you have a UI5 controller open in the code editor!

 

Try it in a workspace with a CAP project at root level, so you see some of its magic immediately: as soon as you finish typing the slash command or select it from the suggestion list, another suggestion list with sample prompts comes up. These are based on the actual data structures of the CAP project.

This means you can simply select the desired entity and service, then the actual full prompt will automatically be entered into the field(but of course you can also write your own prompt!). This full prompt includes even more details than the short prompt in the suggestion list did.

Note that the prompt includes a concrete list of properties and the service URL. This information has been extracted from CAP using good old deterministic code‚Äîno Large Language Model (LLM) used. In fact, this is an area where AI would likely make up ("hallucinate") property names which do not actually exist. Acquiring all this information in advance in a deterministic way not only gives you the chance to review and adjust the prompt with little effort, but also leads to a more reliable functionality overall.

The paradigm: use LLMs (Large Language Models) where they excel‚Äîprocessing and "understanding" language‚Äîand use deterministic code for hard facts and well-defined operations, where possible. 

The AI part starts soon enough, when you submit this prompt. It proposes a specific app setup, highlighting the key choices for you to review. For example, it will suggest a sensible name (if you didn't provide one) or suggest the best location inside the project structure (which it knows from its context).

But you can do more than just review those parameters. A suggested version of the app has already been created behind the scenes, so you can scroll through the 30+ files listed in the box at the bottom and click those you want to preview. If the result already looks fine to you‚Äîperfect. Just press the "Accept Application" button and the app will be set up in your workspace.

Refining the app

But of course you are free to continue the conversation and tweak the result. The LLM in Joule will put its true strength at work, mapping its understanding of your request to what the underlying template can do. No need to type "change parameter x to value y": LLMs also understand you when you are less formal and direct. Look at the below screenshot for an example: it responds almost too compassionately to the developer who is "hesitant about new technologies" and recreates the app with changed parameters‚Äîusing JavaScript instead of TypeScript. The user did not even mention the programming language specifically, but still the LLM decided that changing it would be the best way to accommodate the app code to the user's preferences.

At this stage, you can refine the setup of the initial app‚Äîwithin the limits imposed by the application template used behind the scenes, which only has limited degrees of freedom. We want this initial app to be robust and follow best-practice code. We also want those 30+ files to be created in one fast step. Hence the code is not written by AI, but by using predefined template files we are back in the world of traditional deterministic coding here. You have plenty of opportunity for using AI later on to extend the app from this solid starting point.

Joule is aware of its limits in this step, so it will not say "yes" to every request you throw at it. Asking for "a trillion tables" or other features beyond the template scope will be politely rejected.

Accepting the app

When the preview looks good and you have pressed the  button, the job of this /ui5-create-app assistant is done. After app setup has finished (which may take a while because the dependencies need to be installed), it concludes with hints how to continue, including instructions on how to start the app in your respective workspace setup.

The created application looks roughly like this, with a table and a detail form below. Note: only OData V4 services are supported at this time.

You get this kind of UI when you specify an OData V4 service and entity. If you don't, then there is just a generic "Hello World" success page instead.

Of course this UI structure might not be exactly what is desired in the app or even requested in the prompt, but this is what the template can do. When an OData service and entity but no properties are requested, then the tool tries to detect existing properties. If this fails, the table will be empty (no columns at all)‚Äîbut Joule's success message should then mention this.

After creation

As the assistant suggests, please move to the other Joule assistants /ui5 and /ui5-create-page for developing the app further. In order to create more apps, reset the conversation with the  button at the top of the Joule pane.

Because /ui5-create-app knows that it cannot modify the app or re-create it, it will politely guide you to the options you have, no matter what your request is. It may even give instructions on how to achieve the given goal within a UI5 app, but it will not be able to modify the code and it will make this clear when needed.

AI Learnings

While there is not much more to say about this feature‚Äîsimply try it!‚Äîthere are some facts and learnings about its implementation! If you are curious, head over to the second part of this blog post: Inside Joule: Lessons from building an AI coding assistant for SAP Build.

entry.title: Inside Joule: Lessons from building an AI coding assistant for SAP Build
entry.content:
Flashback: the feature

This is a "making of" article about the implementation of the new /ui5-create-app slash command available within Joule in SAP Build Code. In short, this new feature enables a conversation between AI assistant and application developer about a new freestyle UI5 application to build, with a full-fledged best-practice application starting point as result.

To see screenshots of this feature in action and understand it better, feel invited to read my previous blog post. If you are just here for the background and AI-related learnings‚Äîgo ahead!

 

General considerations

With open‚Äëended prompting, users aren‚Äôt restricted to predefined interactions. The user could ask for anything. In contrast to traditional programming, a prompt input field can‚Äôt be handled with a sprawling web of if/else logic trying to cover all possible use-cases. Attempting this will lead to a frustrating user experience where the user often gets an "I do not understand your request".

Some developers try to mimic this traditional programming pattern when crafting prompts and contexts for LLMs, telling an LLM "if the user asks for x, then answer y". Instead, as demonstrated below, tell the LLM what it can and cannot do and give it a goal to achieve. It's "smart" enough to figure out a suitable response to whatever the user will throw at it.

 

A fundamental choice

Looking at this specific feature in the specific environment, the implementation options on the table were (for a variety of reasons) these two:

  • Either just provide a system prompt (a prompt that is added behind the scenes in addition to what the user typed) without interfering with the specific prompts and replies entered during the conversation.
  • Or adopt a new way of creating an "agentic" multi-step execution plan. Similar to a guided activity, this would allow phases of data collection, possibly in different steps for different data, then an app creation step and so forth.

Surely "agentic" and "well-defined steps" sound good for app creation from a template, no? In fact, the initial implementation started like this, but it was soon apparent that this would neither provide the expected flexibility nor allow for a truly intelligent app creation experience. Defining phases in which to acquire specific information and having the application code created at a specific stage in this process did not feel right. The user would still feel like clicking through a traditional template creation process, as something specific was expected from the user at every stage, instead of giving the user the freedom to tweak every aspect at every stage. The true power of AI, on the other hand, would be totally underused.

But then again... just a system prompt and that's it? No file read access to explore the environment, no dynamically updated instructions? Is this enough for an intelligent coding assistant?

 

Creating an "AI agent" out of nothing

Consider the now common definition of an "AI agent" which has settled over the course of this year: it's nothing more than "an LLM with tools, called in a loop to achieve a goal". The chat conversation provided by Joule can be our loop, an application template with its parameters is the tool and the goal of assisting the developer to create an app can be stated in the system prompt. Of course a real autonomous agent would require the loop to run without user interaction, but for this feature a loop involving the user is just right.

The system prompt used for this feature literally includes: "You help users create new UI5 applications by analyzing their requirements and filling the project template parameters. [...] Your goal is to gather all necessary information to create a new UI5 application. The application will be generated from a template which has only one page and a hardcoded UI, but can optionally display data from an OData V4 service. [...] You cannot create the application yourself, but the user will see a preview...". There you have it: the goal and the tool!

It then goes on with some behavioral hints and of course a detailed description of what exactly the template parameters do. Finally, it requests each reply to contain a JSON object with the best choice of template parameters according to the current understanding of the user request. The JSON object could look like this example:

{

   "appNamespace": "com.myorg.myapp",

   "basePath": "/path/to/workspace",

   "createAppDirectory": true,

   "framework": "SAPUI5",

   "frameworkVersion": "1.136.0",

   "author": "John Doe",

   "oDataV4Url": "https://services.odata.org/TripPinRESTierService/(S(s5xrj1t51r41s3ooztsynysq))/",

   "oDataEntitySet": "Airports",

   "entityProperties": ["Name", "Address"],

   "runNpmInstall": true,

   "initializeGitRepository": true,

   "typescript": true

}

This JSON object is removed from the LLM response before displaying it, then the application is generated with these parameters, so the user can accept it or request changes. In an environment where tools with a well-defined interface like MCP servers are not enabled, this JSON object as part of the conversation is how the integration with the templating tool is achieved. A note to make this very clear: this environment is not the official SAP Joule assistant running inside end-user applications, as it is now also being enabled for development by customers. Instead, it is a sort of predecessor implementation specifically available in SAP Build Code since spring 2024.

Some of these parameters in the JSON object are more important than others with regards to the user explicitly influencing them or having to accept them. Whether the app code is generated as TypeScript or JavaScript is something the user should not be surprised with after accepting the app! On the other hand, the author name, which is only written into package.json, can be reliably defaulted to the logged-in user name and also very easily changed later on if needed. Hence, the parameter descriptions explain not only what they do, but also how much the user should be bothered with them. As result, Joule usually does not even mention half of the parameters, thus keeping the conversation focused.

 

How to stop the agent

Regarding the state after the app was accepted, the prompt explains "AFTER the user has generated the application, you **MUST NOT** continue discussing parameters for generation, but rather [...] in particular by referring the user to the '/ui5' command for most requests or '/ui5-create-page' for adding pages to the app, because they are much better than you in developing features, as they have the capability to automatically select a suitable context of files.".

This means the transition in the overall process between refining parameters and "no more changes possible" is not a hardcoded step or denoted by changing the system prompt, but rather explained up-front. That's enough. Can you talk Joule into proposing another set of parameters after the app was accepted? Maybe. But its normal behavior is just right: it will explain that the app can not be created again without restarting the conversation. Nevertheless, there are also non-AI guardrails in place to prevent the app from being generated again, thus causing trouble.

All in all, we shape Joule‚Äôs behavior by explaining the templating tool and its limits, by stating the goal and desired behavior towards this goal, and by explaining the general flow, in particular the state after app acceptance. This is enough to guide it to a suitable reaction for whatever the user requests.

Even if the user insists like this:

 

Context, context, context!

To make the entire feature really user-friendly, however, it is not sufficient to write a good prompt, but the context must also provide enough information to the LLM to allow for informed decisions. Hence, information like the list of project root files and folders, whether a Git repository is present, plus CAP service/entity/property info, and more, are gathered (e.g. using the @sap-ux/project-access package). This knowledge is provided as prompt context behind the scenes or used in another way (like as content of the suggested prompts). This makes Joule aware of the environment it acts in, leading to better responses, like automatically avoiding app names that would conflict with existing folder names.

Agentic coding assistants like Cline, GitHub Copilot, Cursor etc. usually have the ability to read files and execute shell commands as needed to understand their environment. In this pure user request + LLM response environment this might have been a bit harder to build. Basically, more tools could have been defined, e.g. by describing other JSON object structures for invoking them. But control would not so easily return to the LLM until after the user has entered another prompt.

But for a narrow scenario like app creation this wasn't necessary. Collecting the most relevant information up front not only provides sufficient context, but also improves performance and reliability by avoiding repeated tool calls and unpredictable LLM loops.

 

In-response prompting

The real-world context, however, changes over time. Specifically, once the app is created and accepted, there are new additional files present.

When developing the UI5 MCP server, we observed that the agentic AI tool (e.g. Cline) using the MCP server often decided to inspect the new app directory tree after creation, causing several LLM roundtrips which cost time and tokens. Or it would run "npm install" again, even though it had already been executed. Or it would make specific coding errors very often in subsequent modifications.

To avoid this, we extended the response of the MCP server after creating the app. Normally, it contains just the success message. But now it includes a full list of generated files, it states that "npm install" was already executed and it instructs how to prevent those coding errors. Basically, the MCP server response added further updated instructions to the conversation context.

Exactly the same principle was applied in this new Joule feature. While there is no autonomous agent loop in this case which would inspect the new files, the knowledge which files were created can be valuable for the conversation with the user. And while the/ui5-create-app command doesn't modify any code after app creation (thus avoiding the coding issues), facts like whether "npm install" was already executed, or whether the created UI5 Table in the MainView is lacking any columns, are useful for giving the user hints how to continue. Therefore, the context is extended by adding a hidden message to the conversation history.

 

Traditional coding has its place(s)

In addition to the process of context collection, deterministic coding is also used after the app has been accepted by the user for making the app consumption as smooth as possible. When inside a CAP project, it for example ensures that the cds-plugin-ui5 is added as dependency. This allows the UI5 tooling, including TypeScript transpilation of the UI5 app when needed, to run as part of the "cds watch" or "npm start" script of the CAP project itself.
 
Also, this dependency and all the UI5 app dependencies need to be installed. Unfortunately, there is a wide range of options and specific setups which might be used for dependency management in the already existing app. Probably npm? With or without workspaces? yarn? pnpm? Others? The code detects what is used and tries to cover the 95% case. The initial setup might not be complete in every scenario, but for most users it will ‚Äújust work,‚Äù providing a good developer experience.
AI is fine and all, but sometimes one has to go the extra mile and do some coding.
 

Key takeaways

  • Use deterministic code where reasonable (because the space of possibilities is bounded and a deterministic and quick result is beneficial) .
  • Use LLMs for language understanding or dealing with an unpredictable range of possible requests.
  • Don't try to "program" the LLM with an if/else prompt, but treat it like an intelligent human: state the goal, options and boundaries‚Äîand let it decide on its own.
  • Provide solid pre-collected context so the LLM can make good decisions reliably.

entry.title: Re: Gpath for JSON in Cloud Integration
entry.content:
@lalit2054_46  thanks for this blog, it inspired us to follow the same approach.
However, as we currently face some performance issue with our Cloud Integration, SAP has analyzed our iFlows and suspects the groovy.util.Eval.x() usage as well as the jsonSlurper.parseText() to be the reason. Although we are not sure yet if this is really the case, the code will make the SAP Design Guideline checks for your iFlow fail and the effected iFlows suspicious, so maybe you can adjust it to follow the latest Design Guidleines:

1.) Replace parseText(String) with parse(Reader)

def request = jsonSlurper.parse(message.getBody(java.io.Reader));

2.) Replace groovy.util.Eval.x with these two lines of code*

String str_gpath_expr = properties.get('gpath_expr');
def gpath_result = request."$str_gpath_expr";

*this will only work for simple json structures, not for arrays

More details about JsonSlurper can be found here:
Parse JSON - help.sap.com 
Stream the XMLSlurper input in Groovy Scripts - community.sap.com 
More details groovy.util.Eval.x() can be found here:
 Eval usage check - help.sap.com 
SAP Note 3246624 - Avoid using Eval or Groovy Shell to evaluate script or expressions
